Award.AwardTitle: EASPI: Creating a landslide hazard map of Christchurch in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
From September 2010 to June 2011 the Christchurch area in New Zealand experienced a series of large earthquakes and aftershocks. In February 2011, an aftershock of the first earthquake hit 10 km south of Christchurch, claiming many lives. Some of those people were killed in landslide events triggered by this quake. Subsequent earthquakes triggered landslides in these same areas. As the city rebuilds, there is a need for understanding the hazards and risks associated with coseismal land sliding. This research will result in a hazard map that can be used by the Institute of Geological and Nuclear Science (GNS Science) and other government decision makers. This research will be conducted at GNS Science under the guidance of Dr. Chris Massey who worked to document landslides triggered by these earthquakes.

In the non-seismic community, research has been done via statistical analysis using data from landslides triggered by non-seismic methods. These analyses use regression to determine how different factors affect the potential failure of slopes. The method is gaining popularity as it produces a hazard map that covers a great amount of area. Using these same methods, this proposal is to do the statistical analysis so that a hazard map can be created of the Christchurch and surrounding area from a database created after the February earthquake. This hazard map can then be compared to the June earthquake to see how well it predicts the land sliding that actually occurred. The main focus of this project will be to create the statistical model which can be used to analyze the data from the second earthquake in subsequent research projects. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Christchurch was rattled by several earthquakes from 2010-2011 in what became known as the Canterbury Earthquake Sequence. The Feb 11, 2011 and June 13, 2011 which were centered under and near the Port Hills south of Christchurch caused extensive landslides. These landslides occurred mostly in residential areas damaging and destroying homes and at least three people were killed.  The February earthquake occurred around noon on a work day which minimized the casualties due to landslides. In contrast, a landslide in Washington State in March of 2014 happened midday on a Saturday when the occupancy of the houses was high and 43 lives were lost. We cannot control when a landslide will occur, but we can understand better where they will occur and through monitoring establish early warning systems as to impending failures.

 

The first step is to understand where landslides occur.  A trained geomorphologist can identify areas where there is landslide potential by examining terrain maps. This though is a labor intensive process, which takes time and man hours. To aid this work, I developed a method that highlights areas where landslides might occur by the type of failure mechanism. With an understanding of the geomorphologic processes and type of landslides which occur in an area a map can be derived to highlight areas prone to landslides, cutting down on the area required to examine.

 

The description of landslides figure is a simplified model of the four types of landslides that were common to the Port Hills during the earthquake events. Even though this model was developed with earthquake triggered landslides, it can be applied to any type of landslide knowing the geomorphology and type of failure mechanism. Each of these landslide failure mechanisms was unique in their manifestation on the terrain. These manifestations were translated into terrain parameters which used a digital elevation model to highlight areas where these terrain parameters matched creating a hazard map.

 

Banks Peninsula, which is south of the Port Hills has similar geology to the Port Hills so the model developed for the Port Hills could be applied to Banks Peninsula as seen in the landslide hazard map of Banks Peninsula. The model highlighted where the four different types of landslides could occur. These areas are a fraction of the whole area of the map which cuts down on the manual work needed to be done to find where landslide risks occur. 

 

Through this processes, inventory maps which are the first essential step to understanding landslide hazards can be expedited so that the understanding needed to protect the life and property of citizens can be achieved.
